Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: In January of 1870 American troops massacred over 200 Piikani people near the Marias River in present-day Montana.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: In January 1870, American troops massacred over 200 Piikani people near the Marias River in present-day Montana.

evidence.text: On November 19, 1794, Jay’s Treaty20 was signed by trade representatives between U.S. and Britain, resolving trade and border disputes. Article III of the Treaty excludes Indigenous people from paying duty on goods carried across the border.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: On November 19, 1794, Jay’s Treaty was signed, excluding Indigenous people from paying duty on goods carried across the border.

evidence.text: On March 2, 1799 Congress passed the Tariff Act of 1799, exempting Indians from tariffs.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: On March 2, 1799, Congress passed the Tariff Act of 1799, exempting Indians from tariffs.

evidence.text: The Oregon Treaty of 1846 resolved disputes between the U.S. and Britain and confirmed the 49th parallel as the boundary but did not address or limit the trade and passage rights of Native Americans as set out in the Jay Treaty.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The Oregon Treaty of 1846 resolved disputes and confirmed the 49th parallel as the boundary.

evidence.text: In July of 1855 the U.S. Government signed the Treaty of Hell Gate with the Confederated Tribes of the Flathead, Kootenay, and Upper Pend d’Oreilles.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: In July 1855, the U.S. Government signed the Treaty of Hell Gate with the Confederated Tribes of the Flathead, Kootenay, and Upper Pend d’Oreilles.

evidence.text: In 2024 Senator Steve Daines cosponsored the “Tribal Border Crossing Parity Act,” to acknowledge protections under the Jay Treaty of 1794 and to eliminate the 50 percent blood quantum requirement for members of federally recognized tribes when exercising their treaty‑protected right to cross between the U.S. and Canada freely.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: In 2024, Senator Steve Daines cosponsored the Tribal Border Crossing Parity Act to acknowledge protections under the Jay Treaty of 1794 and to eliminate the 50 percent blood quantum requirement for members of federally recognized tribes when exercising their treaty‑protected right to cross between the U.S. and Canada freely.

evidence.text: On February 1, 2025, three Executive Orders declared a national emergency due to increased immigration and fentanyl flows into the United States. Under the stated emergency, the Executive Orders imposed tariffs on goods from Canada, Mexico, and China.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: On February 1, 2025, Executive Order 14193 declared a national emergency and imposed tariffs on goods from Canada, Mexico, and China.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Susan Webber represents businesses and has personal relationships across the U.S. Canada border. Goods imported to the tribal communities come across at ports of entry in Montana, some of which lie exclusively within tribal lands.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff Susan Webber represents businesses and has personal relationships across the U.S. Canada border.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Jonathan St. Goddard paid $308 tariff on the part that was $1,252.89 (U.S. Dollars), increasing his costs for ranching substantially.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff Jonathan St. Goddard paid a $308 tariff on a replacement part purchased in Saskatchewan.

evidence.text: Executive Order 14197 paused the implementation of tariffs until March 4, 2025.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Executive Order 14197 paused tariff implementation until March 4, 2025.

evidence.text: Executive Order 14231 amended the tariffs to include a 25% duty on all steel and aluminum imports from Canada.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Executive Order 14231 amended tariffs to include a 25% duty on all steel and aluminum imports from Canada.

evidence.text: Tariffs increased costs for tribal businesses and led to cancellation of contracts.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Tariffs increased costs for tribal businesses and led to cancellation of contracts.

evidence.text: Canada announced retaliatory tariffs of 25 percent on over $100 billion worth of U.S. goods.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Canada announced retaliatory tariffs of 25 percent on U.S. goods in response to the tariffs.

evidence.text: The fact sheet accompanying Executive Order 14193 references Canada, Mexico, and China without differentiation.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The fact sheet accompanying Executive Order 14193 references Canada, Mexico, and China without differentiation.
